review_title: Unconcerned with realities of customer expectations, retail, and employment norms in the US.
pros: Some limited flexibility in setting own schedule. Employee discount makes the already great deals incredible.

Upper management is more concerned with self advancement than performing their roles adequately or even competently. Complete lack of team spirit among management with several of the members hustling to simply make themselves look good.

English skills among upper management are middling to poor for a team spearheading a retail expansion to the US. This led to significant lost time due to inability to communicate clearly, and a feeling of inferiority American employees, as conversations among non native English speakers invariably defaulted to French or Spanish.

Constant introduction of new top priorities created lack of focus and progress for the entire organization.

All decision making is at the whim of the CEO who provides no context to his outlandish demands, nor will he speak with anyone but a handful of the expatriate management team. This is completely at odds with their often stated ideal of a "flat" organization, where everyone is supposed to feel empowered to take the actions they feel will make a difference.
advice_to_mgmt:
Immediately stop pouring all resources into garnering social media engagement, and focus instead on fixing the systemic problems at the core of the business.

Specifically:
Insist all upper management is trained in effective people management skills.

Demand all tech and web integrations meet some standard of justification before implementing. Simply thinking a feature is cool is not reason enough.

Hire experts in inventory & warehouse management, and pick/pack operations to ensure you are able to actually ship the items you take orders for.

Trust your American employees judgement, and allow them to do the jobs they were hired for as they see fit. Constant micromanagement of them smacks of arrogance and ignorance.

review_title: Massive potential marred by narrow-minded management!
pros:
*Hard to find many but the company affords the employees the opportunity to devote some of their time to the individual "mission", which can be in any field in the company like IT, marketing, supply chain, etc.
* Can play sport!
* 25% staff discount!
* Opportunity to meet people all over the world.
Advice for future employees: Better be a part-timer: clearly defined responsibilities and good penalty rates for weekends.
cons:
- Emphasis on brainwashing employees by exploiting their passion for sports and turning them into retail slaves.
- Preference to backpackers from Europe, toxic work environment with Europeans having little regard to egalitarian Australian working culture.
- Widespread discrimination
- Lying to employees is commonplace.
- Upper Management defensive to suggestions, lying to staff about their potential career and their roles at Decathlon- in our case, the company over hired staff to work during implantation (building the store from scratch which sometimes involved heavy lifting and working in the sun), then 2 weeks after store opening a lot of employees were given redundancy notices citing poor sales. Not a good way to treat the staff, definitely.
- Rostering issues, they use excel and google docs as their rostering platform. Last minute changes to rosters without notifying staff.
- Lack of clear communication regarding company policies.
- Not enough reward for effort: below average pay.
- Little regard for work/life balance.
- Too much emphasis on facing of the products and little about customer experience.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Hire more Australians in management roles. I understand that it is a European company but you can't have everyone working behind the scenes on Finance, IT, Supply, operations, etc from Europe.
- Restructure, Australia is different from EU/UK, understand the Australian psyche. You are losing out on so much potential.
- Be open to ideas and suggestions and implement them.
- Spend more on Marketing/Media. Digital platforms are good but nothing beats good old radio while driving.
- Be more professional with site feasibility and sales forecasts to avoid over hiring and making people redundant in the future.
It is still a new company so the company has time to learn from its mistakes.

review_title: I have worked as a part-time sales assistant at Decathlon Italia for 3 months, winter season.
pros:
- salary (as a student, I have never found another part-time job from which I could earn the same amount of money)
- young and lively environment
- only a couple of days for the training, then they want you to learn while working
- flexible schedule, good distribution of working hours (5 hours x 4 days a week)
- possibility to work during the weekend (might be a con, but as a student it was a huge plus, also because the hourly salary is higher)
cons:
- chaotic and quite useless group interview... but maybe I was just very unlucky with the interviewer!
- working during the weekend (see pros also)
- they let me know that my contract was not going to be renewed only on the last day of work... they could have told me a little sooner
- for seasonal sales assistants (which is what I was... had they told me so when I was signing the contract, I wouldn't have expected them to renew my contract at the end of the 3 months) : they don't really care whether you know about sportswear or not. You have to learn by reading the descriptions of the products by yourself. When you get to deal with more demanding clients, they immediately realize you don't know what you are talking about... and it's quite frustrating! (I had specified in my application that I had knowledge about swimming and fitness equipment, but I was sent to hiking and skiing area...)
advice_to_mgmt:
- train sales assistants more, at least a couple of days and about the basics... especially if you have them work for a sports category they do not belong to.
- group interviews might be arranged and organized a little better

Low paid, hard working members of staff have very little incentive to stay or work extra hours for you if they are subjected to your hostility and aggression when they are at work.

review_title: Great company with great people and exciting future.
pros: Decathlon UK is an exciting place to be, and especially now with their intensive expansion throughout the UK. Also, there is good capacity to work your way up the ladder, and the staff are all dedicated to provide great training to new staff and take pride in strong sales and customer satisfaction. Although it's a retail environment, it's far more interesting than any other and the products are superb. While all the general managers in store were great, my direct manager was particularly brilliant to work for, and really cared in developing my skills and experiences beyond the department.
cons: Base salary for a full time Sports Advisor not great, with few perks to compensate. Therefore not quite 5 stars. Quite a high turnover of staff in the time I was there, but some people I know couldn't hack the hours, intensity of busy days and customers. Working hours were also annoying, with regular patterns of a late shift (9pm finish) being followed by an early start the next day.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work of driving the company forwards, and be sure to identify and invest in the people who really care about that (whether they're new or have been with the company long-term) and reward them!

If there is anyone who will ever read this...

Although I believe what I will say is not deep science but common sense... this is my advise and suggested management lines:

Self criticism is a powerful tool for authentic leaders
Constructive criticism, even any type of non-agressive criticism, should be use as a fuel for motivation and improvement and not be possibly taken as a personal attack or judgement.
The changes needed should be reflected by the leader's exemplary behavior.
Finding the right profile for a position does not finish nor is only focused on the recruitment process, keeping a high level profile requires a high level of leadership.
Empathy is very important.

If a management model is proved to not be working, or at some point stopped working over the years, makes sense to put an effort to adapt the model to the real needs, the environment, and the work culture of the country. Why keep swimming against the flow?
And finally matching the real values to the written ones should work just fine.
